sub_title: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate
summary: Experienced Fingerprint Subject Matter Specialist and Accredited Fingerprint Expert with a demonstrated history of working in the Public Safety industry. Researcher in pursuit of a Doctor of Philosophy in Forensic Science (University of Twente), financed by the Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), and in collaboration with the Leverhulme Research Centre for Forensic Sciences, The University of Dundee, Scotland, The Scottish Police Authority, and The National Police of the Netherlands. Progressive, Conceptual, Analytical, and Innovative. Skilled in Forensic Analysis, Friction Ridge Examination, Evidence Recovery and Collection, Expert Witness Reports and Testimony, Negotiation and Networking. Relocated from Melbourne, Australia (March 2018) and spent two years at the NFI. Having been trained and developed under the holistic approach to fingerprint reporting, the main motivation for relocation was to be trained under a probabilistic system. Prior to this, obtained ‘Certificate of Fingerprint Expertise’ in Australia (AFSAB) and spent 13 years as a Forensic Officer with the Victoria Police Forensic Services Department. Interested in computer-assisted approaches to develop, improve, and inform human-based judgments. Passionate about training and education, and the ongoing development of fingerprint subject matter expertise, in particular the articulation and development of expert reasoning using computer-assisted platforms. Advocate for strengthening current fingerprint reporting practices and the movement toward the operational validation of a computer-assisted logical framework. Invited plenary speaker, keynote speaker, discipline convener, and recipient of the 2014 Allan Hodda Memorial Award (ANZFSS).  Advisory role for Forensic Science Regulator (FSR), by invitation. Invited member of the Australian Academy of Forensic Sciences (AAFS), past active member and committee member of the Australian and New Zealand Forensic Science Society (ANZFSS). Member of Chartered Society for Forensic Sciences, UK, and advocate for Engender Change - Transforming Culture Through Leadership (ANZPAA NIFS). Local organising committee member for the 2023 International Fingerprint Research Group (IFRG). Author of winning proposal - ENFSI MP2022 call - Direct Grant: 'Strengthening the reliability of forensic methodology and opinions through computer-assisted consensus'.

treasury_media.title: IAFS 2017 Summary_GIBB.pdf
treasury_media.description: From August 21st to 25th, the Department supported my attendance at the IAFS meeting (21st Triennial Meeting of the International Association of Forensic Sciences Conference) in Toronto, Canada. The primary objective was to deliver a presentation on ‘Recognising and Reporting on Limitations in the Science of Fingerprints’. Other objectives were to gather information in current investigative research on the evolution and expansion in the delivery of fingerprint evidence.

treasury_media.title: Caroline Gibb_Hodda article ANZFSS Newsletter August 2016.pdf
treasury_media.description: From August to September of 2015 I had the privilege of travelling to Europe to investigate the current climate of critical issues relating to fingerprints. My investigation focused mainly on cognition, context management and logical reasoning. Itinerary included Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), University of Lausanne (UNIL), 7th European Academy of Forensic Science (EAFS) Conference, Prague, European Fingerprint Working Group (EPG-FP), Barcelona.

awards.title: PhD SCHOLARSHIP - FORENSIC SCIENCE
awards.description: Unconditional PhD offered by the Director of LRCFS to pursue PhD in Forensic Science (Decision Making - Fingerprints)
awards.issuer: Leverhulme Research Centre for Forensic Science

awards.title: THE ALLAN HODDA MEMORIAL AWARD - TRAVEL SCHOLARSHIP
awards.description: The Allan Hodda Memorial Award facilitated an educational tour through Europe to broaden understanding and knowledge around emerging issues in fingerprint interpretation, reporting and delivery. This involved exposure to best practice and educational workshops on cognitive factors and the movement toward the use of a logical framework, including evaluative reporting and the probabilistic approach to fingerprint examinations. During this tour I visited the Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), the University of Lausanne (UNIL) and included attendance at the 7th European Academy of Forensic Sciences Conference (EAFS) in Prague, and the European Network of Forensic Science Fingerprint Working Group (ENFSI-FWG). I also visited the Dutch National Police Agency (IPOL) and The Swiss Federal Police.

projects.title: Polilight-Flare - An integral tool for the fingerprint examination
projects.description: Crime scene and exhibit examination involving the recovery of latent material has substantially advanced since the introduction of the Polilight-Flare® Plus. For obvious reasons there is a continual need for the advancement of forensically non- destructive developmental techniques across all disciplines. To enhance the chances of recovery, the initial examination phase of a scene or exhibit should always involve a visual examination with the aid of a forensic light source. This is prior to physical and chemical enhancement involving the application of powders and stains. The superior advantage of the forensic light source for the development of fingerprints is its non-destructive, non-contaminating properties. This case study dis- plays the circumstance where the initial application of light using the Polilight-Flare® Plus resulted in a far superior devel- oped latent fingerprint when compared to the same latent fingerprint post powdering. The quality of the powdered finger- print has been considerably and notably reduced, not just visibly but also biometrically. I have represented each latent fin- gerprint as seen on NAFIS (National Automated Fingerprint Identification System), alongside their respective minutia counts and generated biometric scores.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: EVOLUTION AND EXPANSION IN THE DELIVERY OF FINGERPRINT EXPERT EVIDENCE - ADAPTING METHODS FOR LOGICALLY BASED CONCLUSIONS
projects.description: Every fingerprint examiner should be aware of the current challenges that face our science and should be provided all opportunity to be exposed to contemporary approaches that address the challenges. Key recommendations outlined in the NAS report, ‘The Fingerprint Inquiry Scotland’ report, and report on ‘Latent Print Examination: Improving the Practice through a Systems Approach’ are now critically at the forefront of the fingerprint science paradigm. Unfortunately, there has been little movement to embrace the substance of the reports, and accept the need for change in evidence interpretation, reporting and delivery.  Through education and awareness, fingerprint experts across the globe need to significantly increase their collaborative efforts. In turn, training needs to be provided to enable experts to articulate their reasoning with relation to non-numeric conclusions, lack of probabilistic analysis, uncertainty, difference of opinion, institutional bias, contextual bias and cognitive bias. As a discipline, we need to explore urgently the best approach to the changing landscape of fingerprint science particularly with respect to limitations, errors, validity and reliability. It is important to take an accelerated approach toward the assessment of Bayesian logical frameworks to support our currently claimed identification infallibility. Fingerprint experts need to understand/realise the dangers of uncertainty without empirically supported data, and need to be aware of bias, and how to counteract it. It is integral that we treat human errors with openness, yet not allow our reputation regarding validity and robustness to suffer.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: ADAPTING FINGERPRINT EVIDENTIAL REPORTS TO MEET PROFESSIONAL, LEGAL AND SCIENTIFIC REQUIREMENTS THROUGH THE COLLABORATIVE ENGAGEMENT OF PRACTITIONERS AND ACADEMICS
projects.description: When preparing and presenting evidence in criminal proceedings, expert witnesses have an overriding duty to the court to disclose evidence in a transparent and impartial manner. High profile erroneous identifications, the inherent subjectivity involved in fingerprint interpretation and the terminology used, particularly in the absence of objective standards, has resulted in an increase in court challenges across the globe. Professional codes, legal rules and scientific requirements must be met to ensure the evidence meets specific admissibility criteria, and is reported in a scientific manner. To address these challenges a Fingerprint Sciences Group Statement Working Party (FSG-SWP) was formed, with representation from a  range of forensic practitioners; the Education and Training Unit and Fingerprint Specialist Advisory Group, two research specialists affiliated with the Office of the Chief Forensic Scientist, and fingerprint examiners with varying skills and experience. Advice was sought from legal academics, and statements from other jurisdictions were collected for review. The primary objective of the FSG-SWP is to address critical challenges, focus on current controversial topics in the fingerprint community (bias, terminology, error rates, limitations, documentation) and ensure scientific and legal requirements were met. To overcome change barriers and ensure successful transition, all meetings were documented and educational forums were held throughout the process. A focus group was established to review, raise and address concerns and find common ground prior to implementation. As a result a new statement template has been successfully implemented along with a glossary of terms and a statement of limitations. A blind verification pilot has been successfully launched and sing A.C.E. reports are a work in progress with single reports being trialled.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: FACILITATION OF THE ONGOING DEVELOPMENT OF FINGERPRINT SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTISE
projects.description: Although there is continually emerging evidence that considerable expertise exists in the fingerprint domain, major knowledge gaps still exist regarding the development and maintenance of expertise, and the reliable application of scientific methods and principles. Strong scientific leadership is imperative to drive change and improvement. Leaders with strong understanding of scientific principles enables the progression of scientific initiatives, active engagement with external sources, promotion of best practice and contributes to the ongoing development of fingerprint examiners.  Most importantly, leaders can provide support for the expansion of fingerprint examiner subject matter expertise. The framework must be structured to ensure that information relevant to task expertise is covered, and that examiners are conversant with limitations, risks and potential sources of error. Continuing professional development after certification is critical for ensuring the maintenance or growth of expertise.  Thus, providing examiners with opportunities to practice and receive feedback on the full myriad of tasks is necessary to minimize error and maximize the reliability of fingerprint evidence.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: RELIABLE APPLICATION OF FINGERPRINT SCIENCE - INCREASED AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF COGNITIVE FACTORS
projects.description: Reliability within the science of fingerprints is multifaceted. To determine what factors affect overall reliability it is necessary to separate fundamental aspects relating to methodological application. Reliability requires a solid foundation - strong adherence to scientific principles, maintenance of validated standardised protocols and the ongoing ability to measure accuracy.  This presentation will discuss how to achieve reliability at each suggested level: (1) Reliable application of ACE-V methodology (adherence to scientific principles, capturing interpretive judgments, mitigating human factors) (2) Individual examiner reliability (Intra-examiner variability, sufficiency thresholds, decision thresholds) and (3) Reliability within an organisation (inter-examiner variability, overall accuracy, error rate). Examples of potential avenues of improvement to current practice will be discussed, such as how the development of robust validated SOPs may serve to mitigate error and enhance practice, or how to capture examiner reasoning to make the process transparent to fact-finders. Any application needs to coincide with organisational policy to protect the individual from factors which may affect judgements. The level of individual examiner reliability can be captured by fit-for-purpose proficiency tests that measure individual performance.  Enhancing the reliability of fingerprint science will require attention to processes, protocols and examiners at multiple levels, but there is a vast body of literature, recommendations and knowledge that the community can build from in these activities.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: Recognising and Reporting Limitations in the Science of Fingerprints
projects.description:
Co-author. Continuous improvement is integral to the progression of fingerprint science.   Practitioners must understand their accountabilities and the risks associated with failing to keep abreast with current literature. Attempts must be made to critically analyse recommendations that have been published in recent authoritative reports, and bridge the existing gaps. One recurring theme in these critical reports is the need to move towards transparency in reporting fingerprint conclusions.  Part of this shift involves the requirement to state any limitations that exist within the fingerprint science, and what may affect the evidence being presented.  In the Australian adversarial system, fingerprint expert reports are bound by legal requirements. In Victoria, if an expert report is requested as per the County and Supreme Court Practice Direction, it must specify any limitations or uncertainties affecting the reliability of the methods or techniques used, the data relied on to arrive at the opinion(s), as well as any uncertainties affecting the reliability of the opinion stated as a result of insufficient research or data. 
It is important for fingerprint practitioners to have an understanding of the limitations within their field, and to accurately report and articulate them in a manner that is understood by a lay person.  And so these questions are posed - what limitations exist within the science of fingerprints?  Do practitioners agree on what constitutes a limitation in their field of expertise?  How can limitations be reported and articulated?  This presentation will consider and discuss limitations at foundational and practitioner levels, inclusive of error rates, cognitive factors, lack of probabilistic analysis, absence of fingerprints, ageing of fingerprints and the subjective nature of sufficiency determination.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: Fingerprint Crime Scene, Mortuary and Laboratory Induction Package
projects.description: Development of an the first 'Operational Induction Package' inclusive of a workbook, presentations and, practicals for trainee examiners to obtain their incremental laboratory and crime scene attendance authorisations. Including OHS, policy, procedures and methods for crime scene attendance, mortuary attendance and the development and enhancement of friction ridge detail using various chemical, physical and lighting techniques. Includes continuity - the appropriate recording and reporting of results. Includes multi-disciplinary approaches to evidence recovery and DNA minimisation procedures. (Biometric Services, Fingerprint Sciences Group in collaboration with Education and Training Group, November 2016 – January 2017.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: PCAST Gap Analysis - Fingerprint Sciences Group
projects.description:
PCAST concluded, on the basis of two studies performed with the United States, that latent fingerprint analysis is foundationally valid, although with a higher error rate than is currently claimed. A number of important issues were identified with the valid application of the method, concerning contextual and confirmation bias and proficiency testing. The development of objective, automated methods was seen as critical to improve efficiency and accuracy. A gap analysis was performed on the Fingerprint Sciences Group and submitted to Senior Management for review. 

Fingerprint Gap Analysis. Biometric Services, Fingerprint Sciences Group in collaboration with the Office of the Chief Forensic Scientist (OCFS), 2016

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: Complex Deceased Identification – A Practical Approach
projects.description:
The identification of deceased persons is a key function of the Victorian Fingerprint
Branch with current best practice to obtain an impression of fingers palms and feet using
black powder and sticky white labels. With the high quantity of deceased persons
processed it is important to employ simple but effective methods whilst ensuring the
best quality result is obtained yet minimising the resources required. This poses the
continual requirement for the advancement of best practice. Obtaining fingerprints from
deceased bodies undergoing varying stages of decomposition can be complex at the best
of times. We propose that for complex cases, digital photography becomes the
preferred procedure. This is also inline with improved strategies for harm minimisation,
stress management and the general health and wellbeing of forensic officers being
exposed to a large number of deceased persons per week. This case study focuses on
the more complex situations such as those involving advanced decomposition and
associated putrefaction. We demonstrate a comparative study, utilising biometric scores
generated by NAFIS as a direct source of quality. The lift, the digital image and the digital
image enhanced with Adobe Photoshop® are all compared. In this particular case, the
images alone were found to be far superior in comparison with the lift demonstrating the
benefits of this as an alternative to current methods and in situations where direct
electronic capture is not feasible.

contributors.headline: Forensic Scientist (Accredited Fingerprint Expert/ ex CSI) - Ph.D. Candidate

projects.title: Assessment of the effectiveness of cleaning procedures to rid fingerprint brushes of accumulated human containing material
projects.description: Technological advancements as PCR-STR DNA profiling in the forensic science arena has led to an increased sensitivity in the recovery and reliability of evidential conclusions. This has ultimately led to the introduction of stringent quality management programs involving proficiency testing, validation studies and quality control procedures.  As scientific technological advancements continue so to will the requirement for relevant updates in training and procedures.  There is little risk of transference of genetic material through fingerprint brushes. However, it is a possibility. It is inevitable that technology will advance, sensitivity will increase. This presents a constant requirement in the forensic science community to protect the reliability of results and in turn prevent scrutiny in the public, scientific and legal communities.  Many processes and procedures, starting from initial investigation by police members to confirmation or elimination of the identity of an individual by a forensic expert are involved in the process prior to its admissibility in court. Police members and forensic practitioners must communicate and work together to ensure the upmost integrity and reliability of evidence presented before the courts.  The development for a validated procedure in the cleaning of fingerprint brushes is one aspect of this process and will hopefully eliminate any questions being raised about the origin of an individuals DNA and negate the argument involved with secondary transfer.

profile_positions.title: PhD Student - Forensic Science

profile_positions.description:
Core Capabilities
Managing, high-level, and often complex major crime scenes, developing, recovering and recording fingerprint evidence; Major crime scene multi-disciplinary exhibit processing through integrated approaches; Performing fingerprint analysis, comparison and interpretation; Searching on the National Automated Fingerprint Identification System (NAFIS); Preparing expert reports on both evidence recovery and fingerprint identifications ; Offering expert testimony in court on both evidence recovery and fingerprint identifications; Mentoring trainee experts 

Other Roles
Office of the Chief Forensic Scientist (June 2017 - January 2018). Secondment involved continued investigations into the evolution and expansion in the delivery of fingerprint evidence. This included performing a gap analysis to highlight the need for practitioner engagement, reliable application of the method and logical reporting for the Victoria Police Fingerprint Sciences Group (FSG). 

Lean Enablement and Deployment Program (LEAD). Lean Subject Matter Expert (SME), (July 2016 - December 2019) Nominated and selected to drive continuous business improvement within Fingerprint Science Group (FSG) following the Lean philosophy of business improvement 

Education and Training Group (October 2016 – January 2017) – Seconded into an assistant role for a period of three months to develop the first Operational Fingerprint Induction Package for new Forensic Officers inclusive of workbook, lectures, practicals and log books

Business Improvement Support Officer, FSG - Service Delivery Enhancement Program (SDEP) (December 2015 – June 2016). Supported business improvements using LEAN training in Operational section of FSG. 

Multi-disciplinary evidence Recovery (MDER), 2016. Assisted initial phase development of integrated fingerprint and biology evidential recovery
